reviewText:
This game is one of the greatest masterpieces of the 21st century.
However, let me give you some background first before I review this product:
I was born in a town of some of the most hardcore tic-tac-toe players around the globe, where we all settled our disputes with a simple 3x3 tic-tac-toe. We developed our own culture based off this game, and if you didn't have the skill, you did not belong any where in that town. I went to various tic-tac-toe tournaments across the country, winning all of them. However, the decline in interest in surrounding cities led to the popularity of my hometown to nothing, leaving it in shambles.

Untill this game showed up on Steam.

Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe completely revives the basic tic-tac-toe formula, but adds a new twist, adding layers upon layers of in-depth strats and tricks. This game includes various game modes, that are sure to pique your intrests.
Those modes include:
Classic - A classic 3x3 tic-tac-toe exprience
Classic Forget - The same 3x3 tic-tac-toe, but the oldest 4th game piece is removed, adding more strategies and cognitive thinking.
Ultimate - This is the game's selling mode, and a great reason the pick up the game. In this mode, you have 9 of your basic 3x3 tic-tac-toe boards, in a 3x3 pattern. You have to think of every move you make, and also think one step ahead of your opponent.
Ultimate Forget - This is Classic Forget and Ultimate, merged into one. The oldest 4th game piece is removed from the smaller boards.
Ultimate Forget Total - Probably the most hardcore mode of them all. This mode is like Ultimate Forget, but once you finish a bigger board, those marks can be erased as well! This mode requires lots of thinking and time to outwit your opponent.All of these modes are available against a bot, local multiplayer, multiplayer LAN, and multiplayer over Steam.

In conclusion, this game is a great masterpiece that expands upon normal tic-tac-toe, and adds a new layer of complexity. This game does not have a very steep learning curve, allowing begginers to enjoy, as well as hardcore gamers, such as myself.

Total Rating 10/10
This game has finally brought my hometown to its former glory, as the tic-tac-toe Champions of the Universe.

reviewText:
It's tic-tac-toe. Noughts and crosses for those in the UK.

This rendition is a free indie product, so at least it has that going. The base game's also free if you have pen and paper, so there really wasn't a choice regarding pricing if the developer wanted to stay competitive on the market. I genuinely dig the freeware aesthetic it has going on, sort of like something you'd find on a '100 Games!!' CD that actually cared about itself. I find those collections pretty damn sad, though, so I'm not aware of any that actually do.


As I said earlier, this is tic-tac-toe. If you actually find someone in multiplayer, or invite someone (to find you in matchmaking, of course, since there's no discrete room creation here). you essentially try to make them screw up. If you play against the computer, you set the difficulty to easy if you want any outcome that isn't a stalemate, and even then it's not guaranteed you'll not stalemate.

There's new variations of the game, which is where things get a little crazy. The titular 'ultimate' mode replaces every square in a standard tic-tac-toe board with its own little board. You try to mark the little boards and win them to make a mark on the big board. The crucial thing here is that you're not actually told that marking the top, middle or bottom of a small board dictates where the next player has to play on the big board. In this case, you actually need a tutorial to play tic-tac-toe, a tutorial that you'll only find in the community guides. It also doesn't help that the variations in small board color that let you know whether you can play there or not seem to be designed to frustrate colorblind people and those who use any sort of screen dimming whatsoever.

'Forget' mode erases the last move made that's four moves old. It's interesting until you realize that it basically means any mark that would let you win is erased so the AI can eventually win instead.


The Steam achievements - for a tic-tac-toe game, I will remind you once again - include ones for various flavors of winstreaks and for reaching 'level 50'. They also don't work in classic mode for some reason, but I digress. The worst thing about this game, really, is that according to the minimum requirements it won't run on Windows XP. That's a bit more flattering: this game is also like something you'd find on a fresh install of XP, except not quite as polished.

Despite the detached, sarcastic tone I affected throughout this review, there's genuine value to be had here. If you know someone, whether a Steam friend or an offline friend you communicate with long-distance, who you'd like to mentally wrestle while you ♥♥♥♥-talk them via Steam (because I'm not sure this game even has a chat feature), this is for you. If you're a masochist who thought chess against Deep Blue's extended family wasn't painful enough, you'll like it too.

reviewText:
Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe is exactly what it sounds like, a tic tac toe game on steam. But will you want to play this game ?

This review will be incredibly short as there's not much to talk about here as it's just a tic tac toe game.

The game has the classic tic tac toe game and it also has a tic tac toe ultimate game mode where you have 9 boards and you try to finish three in  a row to win. There's also a game mode where some of the moves you make get erased to make  it a bit more challenging.

Overall there's really not much to talk about here as it's just a simple and fun Tic Tac Toe game.

The game is kind of glitchy. When I played it and won a match the game said I lost and erased my victory, but it only happened once.

The AI is also really smart no matter what difficulty you set it to. It will take you a while to beat the AI because more or less all your games will lead to a draw.

Overall it's a fun game and it's free so if you're bored and have nothing to do, give this game a shot. I give Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe a 7/10

reviewText: [SPOILER ALERT!!!!!]  When I approached the game I will admit I was confused as to what the basic premise of the game was.  While I am aware that these were available on the back of children's menu's at certain kid-friendly restraunts, it being implemented into the digital world was at first rather complicated.  When I first began I instantly sought refuge by approaching it a similar way I did physical copies.  After doing so I received a thumbs up.  This was rather surprising to me, for I had never before got that kind of response when playing the physical version.  So, initially assuming it was implemented to express positive reinforcement, I pressed on.  After a significant amount of rounds I discovered that I was still receiving the same thumbs up that I had when I first started.  Perhaps the game is attempting to create a paradox where no matter what square you choose it will always result in either a positive or negative response.  Perhaps there is no end game.  Then I discovered the 10th square, found in the top right hand corner.  After that the game closed and a feeling of success consumed me.  This 10th square was brilliantly implemented and required the user rid themselves of previous ways of playing in order to beat the game.  In the end I highly recommend this experimental piece of human psycology and how previously held biases influence the players decision making.

Ingredients

1 lb boneless skinless chicken breast (sliced into thin strips)
1⁄2 cup cornstarch (or more, for coating)
2 tablespoons garlic (minced)
1 white onion (sliced)
2 green onions (sliced)
1 teaspoon salt
1⁄4 teaspoon black pepper
oil (for frying)

Sauce
-------
1⁄4 cup chicken broth
1 1⁄2 tablespoons cornstarch
2 tablespoons hoisin sauce
1 tablespoon oyster sauce
1 tablespoon dry sherry
2 teaspoons sugar
2 teaspoons soy sauce
2 teaspoons crushed red pepper flakes (or less, to your taste)

Added vegetables
--------------------
1⁄2 red pepper, sliced
6 leaves bok choy, sliced
1 (8 ounce) can bamboo shoots
2 fresh water chestnuts, sliced
2 ounces bean sprouts

-----------------------------------------------------------
In a medium bowl whisk together chicken broth, hoisin sauce, oyster sauce, sherry, sugar, soy sauce and crushed red pepper flakes. Set aside.

Toss chicken with cornstarch in a bag until all of the strips are thoroughly coated. Heat a deep fryer to 375 degrees. Fry chicken strips in batches until golden brown and fully cooked. Drain on paper towels. Place into the oven to keep warm.

Add a tablespoon or two of oil to a wok over medium-high heat. Add garlic, onion and green onions. Season vegetables with salt and pepper. Stir fry until added vegetables have reached your desired tenderness. Remove from pan and set aside.

Pour the sauce mixture into the wok and cook until the sauce becomes thickened and bubbly. Add chicken strips into a large serving bowl, pour sauce over chicken, add onions and mix well. Serve with white rice.
